intro: Helicodea baraquiniana, commonly known as the Mexican helicodea, is a rare and endangered flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of central Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, it is critically endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival. Its unique morphology and ecological significance make it an important species for botanical study.
